question: What is the SI unit of force?
options: Joule
Newton
Watt
Pascal

question: Define Newton's First Law of Motion.
options: An object in motion stays in motion
An object at rest stays at rest
An object's velocity is directly proportional to the net force acting on it
An object's acceleration is directly proportional to the net force acting on it

question: What is the formula for calculating work?
options: W = Fd
W = Fv
W = Ft
W = F/t

question: Explain the concept of momentum.
options: The product of mass and velocity
The product of mass and acceleration
The product of force and time
The product of force and distance

question: What is the law of conservation of energy?
options: Energy can be created or destroyed
Energy can be converted from one form to another
Energy can be neither created nor destroyed
Energy can be destroyed but not created

question: Define Ohm's Law.
options: V = IR
I = VR
R = IV
R = V/I

question: What is the speed of light in a vacuum?
Explain the difference between mass and weight.
options: Mass is a measure of the amount of matter in an object, while weight is a measure of the force of gravity on an object
Mass is a measure of the force of gravity on an object, while weight is a measure of the amount of matter in an object
Mass is a measure of the size of an object, while weight is a measure of the force of gravity on an object
Mass is a measure of the force of gravity on an object, while weight is a measure of the size of an object

question: What is the formula for calculating acceleration?
options: a = F/m
a = Fd
a = v/t
a = m/F

question: Define the concept of inertia.
options: The tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion
The tendency of an object to resist changes in its shape
The tendency of an object to resist changes in its temperature
The tendency of an object to resist changes in its position

question: What is the formula for calculating kinetic energy?
options: K.E. = mv
K.E. = m^2v

question: Explain the difference between speed and velocity.
options: Speed is a scalar quantity, while velocity is a vector quantity
Speed is a vector quantity, while velocity is a scalar quantity
Speed and velocity are the same thing
Speed is a measure of distance, while velocity is a measure of time

question: Define Hooke's Law.
options: The force required to stretch or compress a spring is directly proportional to the distance it is stretched or compressed
The force required to stretch or compress a spring is inversely proportional to the distance it is stretched or compressed
The force required to stretch or compress a spring is directly proportional to the square of the distance it is stretched or compressed
The force required to stretch or compress a spring is inversely proportional to the square of the distance it is stretched or compressed

question: What is the principle of conservation of momentum?
options: The total momentum of a closed system remains constant
The total momentum of a closed system can increase or decrease
The total momentum of a closed system can be destroyed
The total momentum of a closed system can be created

question: Explain the concept of torque.
options: A force applied to an object that causes it to rotate
A force applied to an object that causes it to move in a straight line
A force applied to an object that causes it to change shape
A force applied to an object that causes it to change size

question: What is the formula for calculating power?
options: P = Fv
P = Fd/t
P = F/t
P = Fd

question: Define the concept of buoyancy.
options: The ability of an object to float in a fluid
The ability of an object to sink in a fluid
The ability of an object to move through a fluid
The ability of an object to change shape in a fluid

question: What is the law of universal gravitation?
options: The force of gravity between two objects is directly proportional to the product of their masses
The force of gravity between two objects is inversely proportional to the product of their masses
The force of gravity between two objects is directly proportional to the square of the distance between them
The force of gravity between two objects is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them

question: Explain the difference between concave and convex lenses.
options: Concave lenses are thinner in the middle and thicker at the edges, while convex lenses are thicker in the middle and thinner at the edges
Concave lenses are thicker in the middle and thinner at the edges, while convex lenses are thinner in the middle and thicker at the edges
Concave lenses diverge light rays, while convex lenses converge light rays
Concave lenses converge light rays, while convex lenses diverge light rays

question: Define the concept of angular momentum.
options: The momentum of an object moving in a circular path
The momentum of an object moving in a straight line
The momentum of an object rotating around an axis
The momentum of an object at rest

question: What is the formula for calculating the frequency of a wave?
options: f = 1/T
f = T
f = v/T
f = T/v

question: Explain the difference between static and kinetic friction.
options: Static friction is the force that opposes the motion of an object at rest, while kinetic friction is the force that opposes the motion of an object in motion
Static friction is the force that opposes the motion of an object in motion, while kinetic friction is the force that opposes the motion of an object at rest
Static friction and kinetic friction are the same thing
Static friction is the force that opposes the motion of an object in a vacuum, while kinetic friction is the force that opposes the motion of an object in a medium

question: Define the concept of electric field.
options: The region around an electric charge within which the electric force is exerted
The region around an electric charge within which the magnetic force is exerted
The region around an electric charge within which the gravitational force is exerted
The region around an electric charge within which the nuclear force is exerted

question: What is the formula for calculating mechanical advantage?
options: MA = F2/F1
MA = F1/F2
MA = d2/d1
MA = d1/d2

question: Explain the difference between constructive and destructive interference.
options: Constructive interference occurs when two or more waves combine to form a wave with a greater amplitude, while destructive interference occurs when two or more waves combine to form a wave with a smaller amplitude
Constructive interference occurs when two or more waves combine to form a wave with a smaller amplitude, while destructive interference occurs when two or more waves combine to form a wave

question: What is the formula for calculating pressure?
options: P = F/A
P = F/d
P = F/t
P = F/m

question: What is the formula for calculating the force of gravity?
options: F = G(m1m2)/r

question: Define the concept of wave interference.
options: The phenomenon in which two or more waves combine to form a new wave
The phenomenon in which two or more waves cancel each other out
The phenomenon in which two or more waves pass through each other without affecting each other
The phenomenon in which two or more waves change direction

question: What is the formula for calculating the period of a wave?
options: T = 1/f
T = f
T = 1/v
T = v

question: Define the concept of specific heat capacity.
options: The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of one unit mass of a substance by one degree Celsius
The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of one unit volume of a substance by one degree Celsius
The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of one unit time of a substance by one degree Celsius
The amount of heat energy required to raise the temperature of one unit force of a substance by one degree Celsius
